A Contractor neutralized the release with vinegar and generated one drum of waste for disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were affected by this incident.

item.title: Report X-2024040052
item.description:
Report X-2024040052

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-05T15:11:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-29
  • City: ANCHORAGE
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: PACKAGE AT THE UPS FACILITY IN ANCHORAGE, ALASKA THAT ORIGINATED FROM AN UNKNOWN LOCATION IN ALASKA WAS SHIPPING UNDER A GROUND SERVICE RATE TO LAYFAYETTE, COLORADO. ALL PACKAGES FROM ALASKA TO MAINLAND TRAVEL VIA AIRCRAFT. OUTER PACKAGE WAS PREPRINTED KEEP FROZEN WITH A PARTIALLY REMOVED LABEL REFERENCING CHOCOLATE. THE PACKAGE WAS NOT GOING TO MAKE THE OUTBOUND FLIGHT ON FRIDAY SO IT WAS REMOVED FROM THE AIR CONTAINER AND SET ASIDE TO REMAIN IN THE FREEZER. PRIOR TO PLACING IN THE FREEZER AND DUE TO THE CHOCOLATE LABEL BEING PARTIALLY REMOVED, THE RESPONDER INSPECTED CONTENTS TO CONFIRM A FREEZER WAS NEEDED. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY FIFTY-THREE ELECTRONIC DEVICES CONSISTING OF CELL PHONES, IPADS, GAMING DEVICES, CAMERAS, AND E-READERS. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM ALASKA USING ACCOUNT V92889, WIRELESS ALLIANCE, 1275 ROCK CREEK CIRCLE, LAFAYETTE CO 80026. UNABLE TO DETERMINE WHO SHIPPED THE PACKAGE IN AK.

item.title: Report E-2024040066
item.description:
Report E-2024040066

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-05T15:11:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-28
  • City: BLYTHEVILLE
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 28, 2024, at 1223 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Blytheville, AR regarding the release of approximately (6) teaspoons of Chlorothalonil 98.5% PCT TC (Organochlorine pesticide, solid, toxic, UN2761, 6.1, II) from (1) 1012.3 lbs. bag. Upon arrival, contractors investigated and found no freestanding liquid or solids but confirmed that a material was released in small patches on the floor and is now completely dried. Contractors swept the entire trailer floor with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (1) 55-gallon DF which was then staged onsite by the contractor in preparation for proper disposal pending analysis.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-05T15:11:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-13
  • City: ROMEOVILLE
  • State: IL

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 18, 2024 at 2000 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Romeoville, IL regarding the release of approximately (1) quart of Ammonium Hydroxide Solution (Corrosive liquid, basic, inorganic, n.o.s., UN3266, 8, II) from (1) 5-Liter poly bottle. The total amount of 5 liter bottles in this shipment was unknown. Terminal personnel cleaned the original spill and needed a contractor to address the leftover residue on the surface. Contractors were dispatched and upon arrival clarified that the area that needed to be cleaned was not the original spill area, but a section of the OS&D area where some of this material was spilled when it was placed into the waste bucket. The impacted area initially pH tested around a 10-11 so contractors utilized Simple Green and Acid Gator to bring it down to a 7. All waste generated was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum which was then staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024040064
item.description:
Report E-2024040064

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-05T15:11:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-11
  • City: SOUTH CHARLESTON
  • State: WV
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee was driving a box truck loaded with a pair of totes and 15-20 55 gallon drums. Everything had been secured prior to leaving the customer's site with ratchet straps utilizing the e-track system in the truck. The road leaving the customer site grades down hill and as the driver was coming down hill he felt the load shift in the truck. The driver stopped at the stop sign at the bottom of the hill and exited the truck only to find that there was material leading from the front side of the truck cargo box. The totes had shifted and pulled the e-track away from the side of the truck, broke the clip that goes into the e-track, and slid forward in the cargo area of the truck, pushing a pallet jack into a poly drum filled with mostly water with trace amount of solvent. A corner of the pallet jack punched a hole in the poly drum releasing the contents out into the truck cargo area which left the truck and spilled on the road. The Veolia driver called the local Fire Department to respond to the spill. WV DEP was on scene along with a third party ER group to clean up the material left on the road. The road was closed both directions for a period of time until clean up of the road and berm soil were complete. Note that after further investigation the drum that was damaged was over 96% water with trace amounts of organic compounds. This was not an RQ release that required reporting.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XKC experienced a UN3266 Chemtreat FlexPro CL5793 release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 ounce of product released to the poly tote packaging only. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized along with oil dri and PPE into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-04T15:13:28+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-09
  • City: AZUSA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee was unloading drums from a trailer at Veolia's ten day intransit facility in Azusa, CA. The employee used a forklift with a drum grabber attachment to pick up the 55 poly drum by it's lip. Prior to moving the drum, the drum appeared to be in good condition as there was no visible deficiencies identified by the forklift operator. Once the employee began to back up the drum, the drum lip broke off causing the drum to fall and break. Approximately 20 gallons was released onto the trailer and cement floor (all in secondary containment). The spill was immediately cleaned up. After investigating the incident, Veolia believes that the plastic was brittle but unfortunately, we are not sure of the cause of the brittleness since the site only utilizes a few of these drums.

  • Description: On 03/07/2024, at 1232 hours, personnel in the CSXT Walbridge, OH yard, discovered CHIU 258609, a loaded container of Waste Environmentally Hazardous Substance Solid N.O.S. (Benzene, Mercury UN3077 Class 9), leaking. The container was isolated and the shipper, Clean Harbors, notified. HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the container leaking from the door seam. It was presumed the release was due to a combination of an ineffective door seem and either a failure, or improper installation, of the boxâ€™s poly ethylene liner. Contractor personnel secured the package by applying additional sealant to the rear door of the container. The container was removed from the rail transportation and transported offsite via highway by the shipper. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipperâ€™s representative (Angel Villa 972-533-4154).

  • Description: On March 26, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of paint was punctured by a forklift and released approximately thirty (30) gallons of product to the trailer interior and one (1) gallon to the underneath of the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. LSH patched the metal drum and placed it into one (1) 95-gallon poly overpacked drum. LSH personnel deployed granular absorbents to the interior of the trailer and pavement below to absorb the paint. LSH swept all paint impacted absorbents with hand tools and containerized them to one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. Utilizing degreaser, LSH wiped off impacted surfaces of the cargo shipment and contained all remaining debris absorbent pads and utilized PPE into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. LSH generated two (2) 55-gallon poly drums worth of non-hazardous waste, and one (1) 95- gallon overpacked poly drum of hazardous waste. All waste generated was labeled appropriately and staged onsite for further handling.

The drum was then put into a salvage drum and absorbents were used to clean up any liquid remaining and disposed of appropriately. The clean up was completed by 2120et.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: It was reported a spill was discovered inside of a trailer in Bessemer, AL. The spill consisted of approximately 10 gallons of BYK-A 500 (UN1993), which released from the bottom of a 55 gallon metal drum due to mishandling by the previous terminal. Most of the liquid was dried up by the time it arrived. The SDS was reviewed with the terminal, who stated they would wipe up the remaining liquid with Oil Dri and they would overpack the drum in a 65 gallon poly drum and leave it in the waste area at the terminal to be managed.

  • Description: It was reported a spill that occurred on 2/27 in a trailer in Cartersville, GA. The spill consisted of (1) 5 gallon plastic jug of Zep Industrial Purple Degreaser & Cleaner (UN3266), which was punctured by nails protruding from the pallet, causing a "small" amount of liquid to release onto the container and a small amount onto the wood on the pallet. The Sds was reviewed with the terminal and it was decided they were able to clean it with PPE onsite. The terminal placed the PPE and spent absorbents and product into a 20 gallon poly drum and it was left onsite for the terminal to manage.
